utterances: Well, I just tell them my story, you know.
I tell everybody my story.
I hope it helps.
But I tell them luckily, you have silver and not stainless steel, so you can still get some money out of it.
Just try to cheer them up a little bit.
Joe's pretty cheerful himself these days.
He says he has paid off most of his debts in the six months since he opened his store.
So his California dream is coming true.
For him, there really is gold in them there hills, or them there mini-malls.
Well, all it takes is heat, shock and friction for something to be volatile and go boom.
Emma Atkinson works on U.S.
State Department programs and funding to clear unexploded bombs in Laos.
At a press conference in Dharamsala, India yesterday, the Dalai Lama encouraged reporters to investigate for themselves whether or not he was behind the protests.
But he also expressed frustration with the divisions between protestors demanding independence and his own calls simply for autonomy.
So therefore, some Tibetans and also some - there are supporters - some Europeans, some Indians - very critical about our approach because they are not seeking independence.
The Dalai Lama insisted that his views were known to almost all.
And you know, we are not seeking separation that everybody knows, except Beijing do not know that.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Otherwise, the rest of the world knows that.

But Elliot Sperling, a Tibet expert at Indiana University in Bloomington, says that Beijing knows full well that the Dalai Lama does not advocate independence - they simply pretend not to believe him.
They found the best spokesperson against Tibetan independence, and that was the Dalai Lama.
Since Friday's riots, foreign governments have amplified their calls for dialogue between Beijing and the Dalai Lama.
Sperling says that Beijing has no intention of cutting any deals with the 72-year-old cleric.
They're just waiting for him to die so that they can name a new Dalai Lama whom they can control.
What the thinking has been is, you know, wait until he dies.
But in the interim, constantly get him to say that Tibet should not be independent.
And the more he says Tibet should not be independent, the more the pro-independence activists are marginalized and Beijing's claim of legitimate rule over Tibet is bolstered.
Anthony Kuhn, NPR News, Beijing.

The atmosphere after the State of the Union last night brought back to mind 1995, when President Clinton after sharp Democratic reverses in the Congressional election told a news conference that under the Constitution, he was still relevant.
NPR's senior analyst, Daniel Schorr.

It also recalls 2004, when a reelected President Bush told a news conference that he had earned political capital in the campaign that he now planned to spend on issues dear to him, like social security, tax reform and the war against terrorism.

That capital has now run out, and the speech last night, professionally crafted though it was, reflected the bruising rejection of the president in most of the opinion polls and more significantly in the November election.
There are now growing demands that the American military extricate itself from a conflict that increasingly looks like a Sunni/Shiite civil war.
The usual practice is for a president in trouble on the domestic front to shift his emphasis to the international scene.
In this case, the speech was almost evenly divided between domestic initiatives like health care, social security, energy and immigration and the foreign scene, meaning Iraq, the inescapable subject.
But there was no sign that he had changed many minds.

He talked of trying to avert a nightmare scenario of facing the defeat that would be grievous and far reaching, and he appealed to Congress and the public to give him one last chance to win with his new strategy featuring a temporary military reinforcement.
But that is falling on deaf ears.

Today, a Senate Foreign Relations Committee, acting by design immediately after the State of the Union, approved by a vote of 12-9 a resolution saying that an escalation of American troop strength is against the national interest.
The resolution is what is called non-binding, that is not obliging the administration to do anything.
But it makes President Bush look like a lame duck, indeed.
This is Daniel Schorr.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
Today is the 30th anniversary of the Soweto Uprising in South Africa.
For decades, the whites only government had brutally enforced a policy of racial segregation known as Apartheid and just as ruthlessly crushed any opposition.
By the 1970s an entire generation of anti-apartheid fighters had been silenced.
But on June 16th, 1976, a group of school children in the black township of Soweto decided to hold a protest.
At the time, nobody thought their action would change the course of a nation.
Producers Joe Richman and Ben Shapiro bring us the voices and sounds of what happened in Soweto in 1976.
(Soundbite of newsreel)
Unidentified Announcer #1: Cape Town glowed in warm, sunny weather today for one of its most colorful ceremonies, the opening of Parliament.
It was opened at noon by the president, Mr. Fouche.
The republic has enjoyed a year of peace and tranquility -
All political movements were banned.
Everything was quiet, ostensible.
In terms of the struggle, we were in the doldrums.
They had virtually crushed the movement in South Africa.
It was a bad period for us.
A number of people were being killed in detention.
People were very scared to get involved.
And yet, under the surface, it continued to bubble.
They had locked up Mandela in jail.
But they hadn't looked around to see where are their children and what are they doing?
The student movement, under the leadership of people like Steve Biko, there arose a group imbued with the spirit of black consciousness.
Black people need to defeat the one element in politics which is working against them.
And this was a psychological feeling of inferiority.
There was an emergence amongst black townships of self-definition.
Do you take what your father has taken or do you stand up for what you think is right?
(Soundbite of newsreel)
Many mini-malls and miles away, east of Joe's Gold and Silver in Riverside, California, pawn shops are busy.
They buy and sell gold too, and everything else.
Riverside has one of the top foreclosure rates in the nation and lots of desperate people.
And when people are desperate, when they need to get some quick cash, they come to places like this pawn shop we're standing in front of in Riverside.
It's called Just Pawn It and it advertises two percent interest on whatever you pawn.
So you can come in here to pawn your jewelry.
You can come here to pawn your PlayStation.
Even your car - yeah, you can pawn your car here at this pawn shop.
Let's go in and meet the owner.
The owner is Dwight Kelly of Just Pawn It.
We're seeing plenty of real estate agents are coming in.
Plenty of loan brokers are coming in.
You're hearing customers are saying they're losing their houses.
They're moving out of the area.
Some are saying they're moving in with the family.
Groceries, oh boy.
That and the gas.
Customers are coming in just to pawn, just to put gas in their car.
Unidentified Person: Seventy-five, 6, 7, 8, and 9.. All right.
So please believe this will be gone by the end of tomorrow, because it does go to gas.
Seventy-nine dollars?
Unidentified Person: Yes, that's how much gas costs now.
Matthew McCain has just pawned his wedding ring.
He's divorced, so he doesn't seem that upset by it.
Still, he is pawning his wedding ring for gas.
Unidentified Person: How much you pay to fill up your tank?
You see, gas is astronomical now.
So any money you can get to help on the gas tank is a good thing.
Matthew McCain says he's moving.
It doesn't seem like he'll pick up his wedding ring anytime soon - or ever.
Stuff that doesn't get picked up is sold, and that's where the owner of Just Pawn It, Dwight Kelly, makes most of his money.
The trouble is people aren't buying as much these days, so Dwight's store is full of guitars, jewelry, TVs, DVD players, and there's a collectors set of three feet tall KISS dolls.
And over here we have - wow, lot and lots of construction equipment.
